awd_titl_txt: CCE STEM: Collaborative Research:  Efficacy of Macroethics Education in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical: This award by the Cultivating Cultures of Ethical STEM program in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral & Economic Sciences is managed by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research. The goal of this collaborative project at University of Colorado at Boulder, Tufts University and Seattle University is to evaluate the various ways in which macroethics is taught in STEM topics (both in and out of the classroom), and determine the most effective methods that can then be adopted by others. In order for STEM areas to reach its full potential to benefit society, students must be prepared to engage in broad considerations of the ethical issues that face the profession. Established codes of conduct describe standards for professional behavior, but these largely relate to individual actions associated with individual projects, so-called 'micro'-ethical considerations.  But engineering and other STEM areas fall short of its societal duties, if it ignores 'macro'-ethical challenges - ethical issues that must consider societal implications of technology as well as the collective responsibility of the STEM profession.  Macroethics includes issues such as sustainability, poverty and underdevelopment, security and peace, social justice, bioethics, nanoscience, and social responsibility.  The extent to which STEM students graduate with an understanding of macroethical issues is unclear, and is in need of organization. The research will start with a large survey of STEM faculty across the U.S., followed by interviews of selected faculty who are effectively using a diversity of methods to teach a range of macroethical issues.  In addition, a set of case studies that can serve as models for others will be developed.  Best practices that are identified will be propagated through STEM education via a faculty training workshop and online resources.
  
Technical: There is a need for STEM education to prepare students to address macroethical issues such as social responsibility and sustainability. The extent to which students graduate with an understanding of macroethical issues is unclear and in need of organization. The goal of this research is to evaluate the various ways in which macroethics is taught in STEM topics, examining variations in pedagogy and content between different STEM disciplines and institution types. Macroethics educational practices will be examined through Vanasupa's Four-Domain Development Model, which includes both cognitive and affective outcomes, as well as the impact of social context. The methods that are most appealing and successful for educating women and minority students in STEM will be determined. The research goals will be achieved through: (1) a national survey and targeted interviews of ethics instructors; (2) a case study approach to identify effective macroethical instruction settings based on student surveys and interviews, rubric assessment of student work, ethnographic observations, and surveys/interviews with alumni regarding the impacts of ethics education in their practice of STEM topics; and (3) propagate and scale the best practices of macroethics education using approaches similar to that of NSF's I-Corps-L model. Instructors at Seattle University and the University of Colorado will adapt effective methods in their teaching. Dissemination will include a faculty workshop, project website, and publications.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the research was to evaluate how macroethical issues are taught in engineering, identifying best practices using Vanasupa’s Four Domain Development Diagram as a model. Macroethics encompass the broader societal and environmental impacts of the engineering profession, such as sustainability, poverty, and social justice.

The research project as a whole included four phases: (1) a nationwide survey of engineering educators (completed prior to the start of this sub-award); (2) interviews with engineering educators identified from the survey to represent a range of teaching settings and methods that were potential exemplars of effective macroethics education (completed prior to the start of this sub-award); (3) deeper explorations of about 10 settings for macroethics education including additional faculty interviews, student surveys and/or focus groups, examination of student work, teaching observations in a sub-set of cases, and an attempt to learn from alumni of the course who were practicing engineers about impactful practices;  (4) distilling the research findings to help engineering educators integrate macroethical issues into their teaching. This grant was part of a larger project that included the University of Colorado Boulder as the lead institution, with collaborators at Tufts University and Seattle University. The larger project continues under separate NSF grants.

Intellectual merit: The project advanced our knowledge of how and why educators currently teach macroethics to engineering students. Because the pilot study determined that the term macroethics was unfamiliar to many, the survey instruments and interviews used the language ‘ethics and societal impacts’ (abbreviated ESI). The in-depth faculty interviews identified a range of personal elements (input) and the current environment at the department, college, and institutional levels as being influential. Important differences between departments and among institutions were found. Settings for ESI instruction included required and elective courses, as well as co-curricular activities, utilizing an array of both teaching and assessment methods. In addition, the students themselves and the extent to which they seemed to engage or push back on learning about ethics and/or societal issues had shaped instructors’ teaching practices. The research was unable to make significant progress in understanding the downstream impacts of engineering education in preparing professionals for ethical challenges in their work. This was identified as an important area for future study.

Broader impacts: In order for engineering to fulfill its potential to make meaningful positive contributions to global conditions, it is important that future engineers are trained to consider ethical, societal, and environmental issues in their work. These broader impacts have been shown to motivate women and underrepresented minorities to pursue and persist in engineering, often to a greater extent than majority male peers. However, engineering educators often lack the training to effectively integrate macroethical issues into their teaching. The research team held three workshops to train engineering educators to integrate macroethical issues into their courses using effective teaching and assessment practices. Because disciplinary differences were found in the research, the team presented and published examples for integrating ethics and societal impact issues into a variety specific courses and contexts. This included deep dives into biomedical engineering, chemical engineering, environmental engineering, electrical engineering, and computing disciplines; it also included first-year introductory and senior capstone design courses. If engineering faculty integrate macroethical issues to a greater extent in their teaching practices, more positive impacts and fewer negative impacts of engineering in practice are hoped to result.
